page.title: 11History of Wilton
page.content: First settled by the Saxons about 550 A.D. as a good defensive position and convenient crossing place on the River Wylye. It was proclaimed capital of Wessex in 838 by King Egbert from the Royal Palace in Kingsbury Square, Wilton. An important Abbey had been established by 830. Town & abbey were attacked & burnt by Danes several times.Important as a mint.Granted 1st of many charters by Henry I about 1100 it is the 3rd oldest borough in England.Mentioned in Domesday Book & was seat of Bishops of Wilts until 1045.After dissolution of Abbey in 1539,Wilton House was built on the site by Sir William Herbert & later Earls of Pembroke.Wilton's prosperity waned rapidly with building of Harnham Bridge in 1244.Introduction of weaving in late 17th cent resulted later in Wilton Royal Carpet Factory.
